G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, such that the Superior Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 8, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County and the Defendant conducts business in Middlesex County.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: At all relevant times, Plaintiff was on the Premises for the mutual economic benefit of herself and Defendant, purchasing groceries and other items, and was owed the duty of reasonable care owed to a business invitee under Massachusetts law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: This excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard does not support the proposition that plaintiff was a business invitee owed the traditional ‘business invitee’ duty. In fact, Mounsey abolishes the invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopts a general duty of reasonable care owed to all lawful visitors, making the mutual economic benefit/invitee framework in the proposition inapplicable. The quoted concurring passage simply criticizes retaining a special category for trespassers and does not discuss grocery shoppers or business invitees specifically.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places. Thus it is awkward to leave the suggestion that the basic reasoning of the court’s opinion may stop short of so called trespassers."

Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Pub. Safety, 401.raw_text: Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Pub. Safety, 401 Mass. 418, 420–21 (1988)
Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Pub. Safety, 401.proposition: Defendant’s employee’s statement constitutes an admission of knowledge and is binding upon Defendant under principles of agency.
Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Pub. Safety, 401.case_name: Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Public Safety
Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Pub. Safety, 401.support_reasoning: The case does not say that an employee’s statement is automatically an admission of knowledge binding on the defendant under agency principles. Instead, it rejects the prior requirement of ‘actual authority to speak’ and adopts Rule 801(d)(2)(D), under which an employee’s out-of-court statement is admissible if it concerns a matter within the scope of employment and is made during that relationship, subject to Rule 403 balancing. The opinion is about evidentiary admissibility of vicarious admissions, not about substantive binding admissions of knowledge attributable to the principal as a matter of agency law.
Ruszcyk v. Secretary of Pub. Safety, 401.relevant_excerpt: “The trial judge excluded testimony by DeLuse or Cruise as to Dolan’s statement as inadmissible hearsay not within our common law rule as to admissions of an agent. Under this rule, an agent’s out-of-court statements may be admitted against his principal only where the agent has actual authority to make the statement offered… However, we agree with the plaintiff that the time has come to modify the common law rule regarding vicarious admissions.… we… adopt the principles expressed in Proposed Mass. R. Evid. 801(d)(2)(D) and 403.”

Deaton v. Burroughs, 367 Mass. 382, 385\.proposition: Defendant’s failure to promptly clean the spilled milk, cordon off the area, or provide any warning signs or cones after its employee had actual knowledge of the spill breached Defendant’s duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
Deaton v. Burroughs, 367 Mass. 382, 385\.case_name: O'HARA v. Commissioner of Public Safety
Deaton v. Burroughs, 367 Mass. 382, 385\.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the suspension of a state trooper for political candidacy and service on a city council, focusing on constitutional due process, statutory authority, and the validity of internal police rules. It does not address premises liability, spills, cleanup, warnings, or any duty of reasonable care owed to invitees or customers. The cited case is therefore unrelated to the proposition about a defendant’s duty to clean a spilled substance or warn of a hazard under Massachusetts law.
Deaton v. Burroughs, 367 Mass. 382, 385\.relevant_excerpt: We think the present case involved such a situation, and that the procedure laid down by Rule 18.1 and followed by the commissioner was appropriate, both for the August suspension and for the January suspension. At neither time was there any uncertainty as to the facts; the parties confronted questions of law: whether candidacy for elective public office or incumbency in such office was permissible for an active trooper in the State police.

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82\u20.proposition: Defendant’s failure to promptly clean the spilled milk, cordon off the area, or provide any warning signs or cones after its employee had actual knowledge of the spill breached Defendant’s duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82\u20.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landlord’s duty of reasonable care in maintaining common stairways and the evidentiary effect of violating a lighting statute; it does not involve a spill, cleanup efforts, warning signs, or cones. While Lindsey v. Massios confirms that a landowner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, it does not address the specific scenario of an employee’s actual knowledge of a spill or the failure to promptly clean or warn as a breach of that duty. Thus it is too general and indirect to support the detailed negligence proposition stated.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 82\u20.relevant_excerpt: “In summary, we hold that Massios owed Lindsey a duty to use reasonable care in the maintenance of the premises on which Lindsey was injured. If Massios violated a statutory duty concerning safe maintenance of common passageways within her control, such a violation is evidence of negligence which the jury may consider.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 783–84 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant either created the dangerous condition, had actual notice of it (as admitted by its employee), or had constructive notice because the spill existed for a sufficient period that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The proposition describes the traditional premises-liability standard requiring proof that defendant created the condition, had actual notice (including through an employee admission), or had constructive notice because the spill existed long enough to be discovered. Sheehan, however, explicitly explains that this was the prior traditional rule and adopts the different “mode of operation” approach, which relaxes the plaintiff’s burden to prove actual or constructive notice of the specific spill. Thus, the case does not support the quoted traditional-notice proposition; it supersedes it in Massachusetts self‑service cases.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Under the traditional approach to premises liability, the plaintiff is required to prove a grocery store caused a substance, matter, or item to be on the floor; the store operator had actual knowledge of its presence; or the substance, matter, or item had been on the floor so long that the store operator should have been aware of the condition. … Of the two modern approaches, the mode of operation and burden-shifting approaches, the mode of operation approach is in our view the more preferable, and we now adopt it.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant either created the dangerous condition, had actual notice of it (as admitted by its employee), or had constructive notice because the spill existed for a sufficient period that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case does articulate the general rule that a plaintiff may prove negligence by showing the defendant created the condition, had actual knowledge, or had constructive notice because the condition existed long enough to be discovered. However, in its application, the court finds the plaintiff’s circumstantial evidence insufficient and orders judgment for the defendant, emphasizing that there was no proof the defendant created the condition, had actual notice, or that the spill existed long enough to establish constructive notice. Thus, the opinion describes but does not actually support the proposition as satisfied on the facts.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present… for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 788\u201389.proposition: Defendant failed to implement and/or enforce reasonable inspection and cleanup procedures in a high-risk area such as the dairy aisle, where spills of liquid products are reasonably foreseeable and recurrent.

Mounsey, 363 Mass. at 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier who invites members of the public onto its premises owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors from foreseeable risks of harm.
Mounsey, 363 Mass. at 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case that abolished the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposed a general duty of reasonable care owed to lawful visitors, including members of the public invited onto premises. The provided excerpt is from a concurrence criticizing retention of a separate trespasser category, but the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 expressly adopts a reasonable‑care standard toward lawful visitors. Thus, while the quoted passage doesn’t state the rule, the case at that citation does support the proposition.
Mounsey, 363 Mass. at 707.relevant_excerpt: (From the Mounsey majority, around 363 Mass. at 707–708) “We hold that a landowner owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.”

Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271, 275 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier who invites members of the public onto its premises owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to protect lawful visitors from foreseeable risks of harm.
Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271, 275 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the duty owed by a landowner (including a municipality operating a public parking lot) to persons lawfully on the premises. It cites Mounsey and instructs that a landowner owes a single duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and frames the jury question as whether the landowner failed to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors. This aligns with the proposition that an owner inviting the public onto its premises must exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe and protect against foreseeable risks of harm.
Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271, 275 (.relevant_excerpt: “The town’s duty in the case at bar does not arise from the general language of a regulatory or criminal statute, but rather from the town’s status as a landowner… A landowner owes a single duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on his premises. Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973)… Doherty was lawfully on the town’s premises when she suffered her fall… The town owed Doherty a duty of reasonable care in her individual capacity as a parking lot patron… The case was submitted to the jury under a Mounsey instruction: specifically, whether the landowner violated its duty of care by failing to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition for all lawful visitors.”

Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 685–87 (2015)
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence is established under ordinary principles of premises liability and under the “mode of operation”/recurring hazard approach recognized in Massachusetts for self-service stores where recurring conditions create a foreseeable risk.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly applies both traditional premises liability principles (duty of reasonable care, notice) and the Sheehan “mode of operation”/recurring hazard approach to a slip-and-fall in a nightclub, and holds that the mode of operation doctrine is not limited to self‑service grocery stores. It recognizes that where a business’s chosen mode of operation foreseeably and regularly creates unsafe conditions (recurring spills), the notice requirement is satisfied, and remands for a jury to decide whether the defendant exercised reasonable care. This squarely supports using ordinary premises principles plus a mode‑of‑operation theory in Massachusetts when recurring conditions create a foreseeable risk.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we now state explicitly what was implicit in Sheehan, namely, that so long as the aforementioned parameters for applying the mode of operation approach exist, there is no basis for limiting its application to self-service establishments… Here, the nightclub’s mode of operation included the sale of beverages in plastic cups from bars located on a dance floor. … It was reasonably foreseeable that such a mode of operation would result in a recurring theme of cups being jostled and liquid being jettisoned by patrons onto the dance floor… Whether the defendant exercised reasonable care to protect patrons from such spillage is a question for the jury.”

Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248, 251\.proposition: Defendant’s employee’s admission that he had observed the spill “a few minutes” before Plaintiff’s fall is evidence of Defendant’s actual notice and failure to take timely remedial measures or provide warnings, which constitutes a breach of the standard of care.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248, 251\.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a state enforcement officer was a trespasser when he entered plaintiff’s land in the performance of his official duties. It does not involve premises liability, spills, employee admissions, notice of a dangerous condition, or breach of a standard of care to an injured plaintiff. The case is about statutory and common-law authority for lawful entry onto private property, so it does not support the proposition regarding actual notice of a spill and failure to take timely remedial measures or provide warnings.
Thurlow v. Crossman, 336 Mass. 248, 251\.relevant_excerpt: "The auditor found 'that the defendant was not trespassing upon the land of the plaintiff, but was properly there in the performance of his duties under the provisions of G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 130, § 6A, and c. 631 of the Acts of 1953.' ... It appears from the findings of the auditor that the defendant entered the premises to investigate suspected illegal activities relating to the taking of shellfish in the vicinity, a purpose within the scope of his duties as law enforcement officer for the department of natural resources."

Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.raw_text: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452–53 (1969)
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.proposition: Defendant’s employee’s admission that he had observed the spill “a few minutes” before Plaintiff’s fall is evidence of Defendant’s actual notice and failure to take timely remedial measures or provide warnings, which constitutes a breach of the standard of care.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.case_name: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a bar’s negligence in failing to control a drunken, violent patron who ultimately shot the plaintiff; it does not involve a slip-and-fall, a spill, or an employee’s admission about observing a hazardous condition shortly before an accident. The court’s analysis focuses on foreseeability of violent acts by intoxicated patrons and statutory violations in serving liquor, not on actual notice of a physical condition on premises or timeliness of remedial measures or warnings. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific notice-and-remedial-measures proposition stated.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant, as the operator of a restaurant and bar, was in possession of real estate open to the public for business purposes. It owed a duty to a paying patron to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional… The jury could have found that the defendant’s agents should have tried to stop his drunken staggerings the length of the aisle, and if they did not attempt completely to remove him from the scene, at least should have provided some safeguard for the defendant’s patrons.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff was at all relevant times exercising due care for her own safety, walking normally in a grocery aisle where no hazards were marked or warned against. Plaintiff had no reasonable way to anticipate or avoid the unmarked puddle of spilled milk.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: As a further foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff incurred and will continue to incur medical expenses for treatment of her injuries, including, but not limited to, urgent care visits, diagnostic testing, and physical therapy.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 873\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover for all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and impairment or loss of enjoyment of life.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 873\u.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with damages under Massachusetts consumer protection (Chapter 93A), intentional infliction of emotional distress, and warranty of habitability in a landlord-tenant context. It does not state or apply any general rule that a negligence plaintiff may recover all damages proximately caused by a defendant’s negligence, nor does it list medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life as the standard negligence damage elements. The case is therefore not authority for the broad tort-negligence damages proposition cited.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 873\u.relevant_excerpt:
On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries as a consequence of Haddad's unfair and deceptive trade practices: emotional distress, and the diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.
...
3. Measure of damages for breach of warranty of habitability. On the counterclaim of Gonzalez for breach of warranty of habitability, the judge concluded that Gonzalez was entitled to the difference between the actual value of the apartment in its defective condition and the fair market value of the apartment...

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover for all damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and impairment or loss of enjoyment of life.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability, duty to warn, design negligence, consortium, and excessiveness of a damages award, but it does not set out or analyze the categories or scope of recoverable damages as a legal rule. The description of the plaintiff’s injuries and losses is used only to assess whether the jury’s $440,000 verdict was excessive, not to articulate a doctrinal statement that Massachusetts law entitles plaintiffs to recover all proximate damages including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life. Thus it does not serve as authority for the broad damages proposition claimed.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital where her fingers were amputated and skin grafts undertaken; her disfigurement, including scars from skin graft operations; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff seeks compensation for all such damages in an amount to be determined by the trier of fact, together with statutory interest from the date of commencement of this action, and costs.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff her allowable costs of suit pursuant to G.L. c. 261;
